ratings.comment: He is a very knowledgable guy and very unbiased especially with such a hard to teach topic. A lot and I mean A LOT of reading, (sometimes 100 pages a week) but if you are motivated to learn about the topic, none of the reading is irrelevant. Gives weekly timed quizzes based on reading. I learned a lot though

Prof. Shelef is obviously very intelligent and well-informed about current events as well as the realities of the political world. Did an exceptional job of presenting all political systems' pros and cons (read: didn't try to sway you one way or another). Lectures were super informational and Shelef has a witty sense of humor.

Professor Shelef is extremely intelligent and informed about Israeli Politics. I felt that I gained a comprehensive understanding of their government and how it has come to be. The simulation at the end was very useful and a fun way to put what we learned into practice. He was very caring towards his students.

I enjoyed Professor Shelef's lecture and found his class to be very interesting and engaging. He was very clear about what we needed to know and helped us understand what was going to be tested. He always took questions during his lecture and helped to make sure everyone understood the material. Overall, a very good class.

I liked Professor Shelef's class. There is a lot of material to go through and it is heavy reading but if you put in work, you can get a good grade. Discussion sections are really helpful too. He teaches well.

He is incredibly knowledgeable. I've never taken a professor that knew more about his field. His lectures are interesting and unbiased. He answers questions at the beginning of every class. It's not an easy class, but not too tough for a 600 level course either. I can't recommend him enough

I really enjoyed his PS120 class, he was very straight forward and everything he says is important and to the point. A lot of times PS professors are a little politically biased but he is not. There are only a couple exams and discussion participation for grades but if you read the textbook and attend the lectures its a fairly easy class.
Very well spoken professor. I thoroughly enjoyed his lectures but his exams were not very representative of his lecture. Be sure to do the readings before discussion and exams.

Tests were definitely fair, just a LOT of material to know beforehand. Was probably just my TA, but even when my answers were in depth, they were never in-depth enough. Lectures were pretty boring, since all he did was read off the slides. Sometimes he will say things not on the slides that do end up on the exam as extra credit.

Great professor for intro PoliSci, really funny guy but will grill you if you don't know your stuff.  You will use your textbook but tests and quizzes weren't too difficult or given too often. Young and good with technology.

Although his lectures can seem boring, they are full of information that will directly be on the test. The tests are very easy. The TA I had, Ning, was AMAZING and contributed greatly to my success in the class. However, to my conservative pals out there: he makes many liberal-fueled comments throughout lectures. Usual for UW.

Honestly homeboy just reads off his slides for 75 minutes. Now I'm not saying those slides aren't interesting or that he seems like a bad guy, but if you're not in the mood to sit throughsiel  a man speaking about things that you can read right in front of you, this class isn't for you. He does post his slides online, so that's very helpful.

Shelef is very professional guy who does not waste much class time going off on tangents. Having said that, it can make the class seem like it is dragging on. The course requires that you do a lot of reading that you can sorta skim, but lectures and discussion cover so much of what WILL appear on the exams. Grade is almost entirely based on exams.

This is a very good class for all potential Poli Sci majors to take. Yes, here is a lot of reading, and you really need to work for your grade, but if you come out of the semester not learning a ton of new information, then you did something wrong. Shelef was a very good professor who was clearly knowledgable, and lectures always were interesting.

Nadav Shelef is the best professor I've had here at UW.  He's extremely knowledgable about Israeli politics and makes the lectures go fast even though they are an hour and 15min.  One midterm, a final, an a simulation that actually really helps enhance your understanding of the class.  I gained a really in depth understanding of Israeli politics

Professor Shelef is very knowledgable in world politics and it shows. The lectures are actually very interesting. He posts all of the lecture slides which go very in depth. If you study these, you will get A's on the exams. There are two midterms and a final. He also has a lot of guest speakers come in which makes it even more interesting.

Nice guy but there is a lot of reading. Exams are cumulative and are almost all short answer/essay. No study guides or review sessions and TA's wont tell you anything about the test. Direct quote from TA, "Just review all the notes, chapters in the book, and all the articles and you should be fine."

This class is the most dry, hard to sit through, worst hour and 15 minutes of life. I have never experience a top so boring, and taught in such a boring manner. The amount of readings is absolutely ridiculous and I would say 75% of was a waste of time. The class is not only boring but hard and dense. Nice professor but awful awful class.

Shelef was a very tough professor and this class was extremely challenging and a huge workload. However, it is a very complicated subject and he justifies everything he assigns and doesn't make you think that all the work you are doing is pointless. The research paper was tough but his grading was fair and he is always available to help students.

The Arab-Israeli conflict was a very hard class, but it was very rewarding. You learn and process a massive amount of information, but you gain a great understanding of this immensely complicated topic. Keep up with readings or you will be swamped. The good thing is he gives you a sample syllabus beforehand; you know what you're getting into.
I wasn't in any of his classes two years ago, but if he was a bad professor when he started, he certainly isn't one now. Don't let the older reviews deter you from taking his classes.

I disagree with many of the comments.  I thought both of my classes were well organized and it was easy to know what he wanted.  It is true there was a lot of reading but every class has a lot of reading it seems. Overall he is a very good professor that took great care to make sure I learned something.

Completely unreasonable amount of reading - and this is true for both his undergraduate and graduate classes.  If you HAVE to take him, make sure it is a semester that you have an otherwise very light load.  He is also pretty passive aggressive.

This was my second course with Shelef, and he is just as intimidating and unapproachable as ever.  He does NOT appreciate opinions differing from his own, and let's you know.  Make sure you choose a paper topic he likes or be prepared for a lot of negative comments and a very low grade.  Really, just a very disappointing, self-obsessed professor.

If you are a undergrad, maybe you can get something - again, just something - from him. If you are a grad student, you will find that his seminar is definitely unhelpful. He indoctrinates students with his own points of view which are sometimes very much biased.
Committed to actually teaching me something. He really helped me learn by giving useful feedback.

A really cool guy with tons of knowledge but can his lectures can tend to get dry and drag a little. Packs a lot of information into his lectures but only a chunk of it is important. Fair but challenging exams and big research paper.
The best political science professor I've had thus far.  His lectures are very engaging.
No structure to anything. He does not answer questions. He also does not give expectations on assignments and then grades hard.

I agree with the other commenter. He doesn't make clear what he wants from you; then he waits until after evals are handed in to reveal his true character and gives you an F on a paper that at least deserved a B. Also, the amount of reading assigned in his course is more than double (no exaggeration) what a reasonable professor would assign. Avoid.
No Comments

No stucture to his class. When you ask a question he does not give a clear answer. Also he is unable to clearly state what he expects from assignments. A lot of readings for every class that are boring and hard to understand and he is unreasonable to assign that many readings.Hard grader  with high expectations.
